title: St Modwen accepts sweetened £1.3bn Blackstone offer
text:
St Modwen Properties has agreed a sweetened takeover offer from Blackstone that values the logistics and housing specialist at £1.3bn.

Blackstone made a final all-cash final offer for St Modwen of 560p per share, a premium of about 25 per cent to the closing price the day before the private equity group first went public with its interest. Blackstone had in May offered to buy St Modwen at 542p a share.

St Modwen said it was backing the latest proposal, with Blackstone leaving an option open to making a revised offer if another suitor emerged.

Briefly

Payments group Wise is forging ahead with plans for a landmark direct listing. The fintech, which was last privately valued at $5bn in a secondary share sale last summer, confirmed plans to float on London's standard listing segment by early July. Founders and early investors will retain non-transferable Class B shares holding nine votes apiece. Wise added that it had received more than 60,000 expressions of interest in its customer shareholder programme, OwnWise.

Distributor Bunzl left revenue guidance unchanged in its half-year update, saying a recovery in the food service and retail sectors has been mainly offset by the decline in larger Covid-19 related orders. First-half underlying revenue will grow 6 per cent versus the 2019 period on an operating margin nearly 1 percentage point higher, it said.

Lone Star has conceded defeat in its pursuit of Senior, the aerospace engineer. Senior had rejected a £840m takeover offer from the US private equity firm earlier this week, describing it as “highly opportunistic”. Loan Star had pitched its fifth and final proposal at 200p a share, having gone public with its bid at the end of May.

Crest Nicholson reinstated its dividend after swinging into half-year profit. The housebuilder posted a pre-tax profit for the six months ended April of £36.3m against a loss of £51.2m a year earlier. For the full year Crest targeted adjusted profit before tax of at least £100m, which includes a gain from its recent sale of a film studio joint venture.

Wood Group said in a trading update that improving activity and order book expansion underpinned expectations for a return to growth in the second half. The oilfield engineer left full-year guidance unchanged. First-half adjusted ebitda will be down around 12 per cent to between $255m and $265m and revenue will fall 21 per cent to $3.2bn due to Covid disruption, the company said.

Online casino operator 888 Holdings said it had agreed an exclusive partnership to develop Sports Illustrated online sports betting and iGaming products in the US. 

Beyond the Square Mile

Russia has exacerbated a shortage of European natural gas supplies by quietly limiting top-up sales to customers, driving prices to a 13-year high. Pipeline exports of natural gas from Russian state-backed monopoly Gazprom to continental Europe have dropped roughly one-fifth in 2021 from pre-pandemic levels, despite a sharp rebound in demand and low stockpiles of the fuel.

John McAfee, the cyber security and software entrepreneur, was found dead in a Spanish prison cell hours after the country's high court ruled he should be extradited to the US on charges of evading millions of dollars in taxes. 

Hong Kongers queued for hours to buy the final edition of Apple Daily, the day after the pro-democracy newspaper shut down following the arrests of senior journalists and the government freezing its assets. The tabloid's closure has been viewed as a marker of the deterioration of civic freedoms and Beijing's crackdown on political opposition in the city.
